title: Ex-Philippine president Duterte says he’s ‘responsible’ as ICC takes him into custody | The Straits Times

parsed_web_results.title: Ex-Philippine president Duterte says he’s ‘responsible’ as ICC takes him into custody | The Straits Times
parsed_web_results.content:
THE HAGUE - Former Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte said he was “responsible” as the International Criminal Court (ICC) took him into custody on March 12 to face charges of crimes against humanity over his war on drugs.

The ICC, based in The Hague, has said there were “reasonable grounds” to believe Mr Duterte committed the crime against humanity of murder as an “indirect co-perpetrator” during the anti-drug campaign that rights groups estimate killed tens of thousands of people.

“I am the one who led our law enforcement and military. I said that I will protect you and I will be responsible for all of this,” Mr Duterte said in a video shared on his and a close adviser’s Facebook pages as he was about to land in the Netherlands.

“I have been telling the police, the military, that it was my job and I am responsible,” said the 79-year-old, the first Asian former head of state to face charges at the ICC.

The court rules on the world’s worst crimes, including war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide.

A spokesman confirmed Mr Duterte was in court custody after he arrived in Rotterdam by private jet.

A vehicle thought to be carrying him drove into the ICC detention centre in The Hague past dozens of supporters, some shouting, “Bring him back”, and waving national flags.



“There has been no due process,” caregiver Duds Quibin, 50, told AFP. “This is kidnapping. They just put him on a plane and brought him here.”

The centre, located close to the North Sea coast, offers each prisoner an individual cell equipped with a computer to work on their case, along with an outdoor exercise area.

Mr Duterte will be held here until an initial court appearance, likely in the coming days.

Speaking to AFP outside the ICC, Mr Gilbert Andres, a lawyer representing victims of the drug war, said: “My clients are very thankful to God because their prayers have been answered.

“The arrest of Rodrigo Duterte is a great signal for international criminal justice. It means that no one is above the law.”

## ‘Oppression and persecution’

Before her father’s departure, Vice-President Sara Duterte said he was being “forcibly taken to The Hague”, labelling the transfer “oppression and persecution”.

On March 12, she flew from Manila to be by his side.

A media relations officer for the Vice-President told AFP that she had since landed in Amsterdam and planned to hold a press conference at The Hague on March 14.

A one-time alliance between President Ferdinand Marcos Jr and the Duterte family has exploded spectacularly since the 2022 presidential election, when Ms Duterte was Mr Marcos’ running mate.

She is currently facing a Senate trial on a number of charges, including corruption and an alleged assassination plot against Mr Marcos.

Mr Duterte himself had earlier taken to social media, claiming that the Supreme Court would step in and prevent his transfer.

At a church in the Philippine capital Manila, people whose family members had been killed in the “drug war” welcomed the arrest.

“Duterte is fortunate, there’s due process for him. There was no due process for my son” Angelito, said Ms Emily Soriano at a press briefing organised by a local rights group.

Mr Duterte “will be lying down on a good bed, my son is already rotting at the cemetery”.

UN human rights chief Volker Turk described the arrest as “a very important step towards seeking accountability for the thousands of victims of killings”.

China, however, warned the ICC against “politicisation” and “double standards” in the Duterte case, saying it was “closely monitoring” it.

Former Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte arrested on ICC warrant over drug war - YouTube

The high-profile case came with the ICC currently under sanctions from US President Donald Trump.

Mr Trump is unhappy at the court for issuing an arrest warrant for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over alleged crimes committed during the Gaza war.

ICC chief prosecutor Karim Khan said the fact that the arrest warrant had been carried out “is important to victims” and proof that “international law is not as weak as some may think”.

## ‘Davao Death Squad’

The Philippines quit the ICC in 2019 on Mr Duterte’s instructions.

But the tribunal claims jurisdiction over killings up to then, including ones in the southern city of Davao when Mr Duterte was mayor.

The ICC said in its arrest warrant that there were “reasonable grounds to believe” at least 19 people were murdered in the city by members of the “Davao Death Squad”, headed by Mr Duterte.

Additionally, at least 24 people were killed by Philippine police in various locations, judges believe.



Dozens of supporters, some waving Philippine flags, gathering outside the ICC detention centre as they awaited former president Rodrigo Duterte’s arrival.

On March 9, Mr Duterte lashed out, labelling ICC investigators “sons of whores” while saying he would “accept” an arrest.

The former president is still hugely popular among many who supported his quick-fix solutions to crime, and he remains a potent political force.
